concepts.name: Categorical Imperative
concepts.description: Kant's principle that moral actions must be universalizable and treat people as ends in themselves, never merely as means.
arguments: Act only according to maxims you could will to be universal laws
Treat humanity always as an end, never merely as means
Moral worth comes from acting from duty, not inclination
counterArguments: Too rigid and doesn't account for consequences
Conflicts can arise between different duties
Difficult to determine what can be universalized
concepts.modernRelevance: Foundational for human rights theory and medical ethics

concepts.name: Existential Authenticity
concepts.description: The idea that individuals must create their own meaning and live according to their freely chosen values rather than conforming to external expectations.
arguments: Humans are condemned to be free and must choose their essence
Authenticity requires taking full responsibility for one's choices
Bad faith involves denying one's freedom and responsibility
counterArguments: Complete freedom may be an illusion due to social constraints
Some values may be objectively better than others
Authenticity can lead to moral relativism
concepts.modernRelevance: Influences psychology, therapy, and discussions of personal identity

concepts.name: Utilitarian Calculus
concepts.description: The method of determining the rightness of actions by calculating their consequences in terms of overall happiness or well-being produced.
arguments: Actions are right insofar as they promote happiness
The greatest good for the greatest number should guide decisions
Pleasure and pain can be quantified and compared
counterArguments: Difficult to measure and compare different types of happiness
May justify intuitively wrong actions if they maximize utility
Ignores individual rights and justice concerns
concepts.modernRelevance: Used in policy analysis, economics, and AI ethics

schools.name: Stoicism
schools.description: Ancient philosophy emphasizing virtue, wisdom, and acceptance of what cannot be changed
corePrinciples: Focus on what you can control
Virtue is the only true good

schools.name: Existentialism
schools.description: 20th-century philosophy emphasizing individual existence, freedom, and choice
